MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
2023C0000362
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB630201335
Licensee Group Organization: Oakland Family Services
Licensee Designee: Jaimie P. Clayton
Chief Administrator: Jaimie P. Clayton
Agency Name: OAKLAND FAMILY SERVICES
Agency Address: 114 ORCHARD LAKE RD
PONTIAC, MI 48341-2244
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 07/05/2024
Capacity:

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207- Staff Responsibilities.
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The agency refused to obtain needed medical care services
related to Child A's leg, required tongue surgery, and possible
Autism diagnosis. The agency refused to obtain a second opinion
for the child’s issues as ordered by the court.
Investigation Interviews
Complainant
2

On 4/4/2023 I interviewed, the Complainant, Guardian Ad Liem
(GAL) X by telephone. GAL X indicated in the complaint that
Child A presents with multiple physical issues including leg
dragging, needing tongue surgery and multiple signs of autism.
GAL X indicated that at a review court hearing on 1/23/2023 the
court ordered the Oakland Family Services (OFS) agency to
obtain a second opinion related to Child A’s medical issues prior
to the next court date on 3/28/2023. GAL X reported that a few
days prior to the 3/28/2023 OFS reported it was relying on Early
On for the fulfillment of the assessment. GAL X reported the court
found that Early On services does not comply with the court’s
order for a second opinion.
GAL X reported she had concern with whether the OFS worker
had actually made an Early On services referal. GAL X said
perhaps OFS had made the referral because the foster parents
reported they were informed by OFS that Early On would come to
their home in early March of 2023. By the end of March 2023
Early On had not come to the foster home, so services were likely
not provided to Child A with respect to her physical and mental
health issues. GAL X reported Early On “is terrible anyway”, and
Child A requires services related to her leg and tongue. GAL X
advised that Child A requires a complete assessment of the
aforementioned health care issues via a hospital provider like
Beaumont Hospital. GAL X reported she is not certain of all the
services required for a child with Autism, but Child A needs to be
diagnosed. GAL X reported Child A has a sister who is diagnosed
with Autism, therefore the urgency to determine Child A’s needs.
GAL X said Child A’ primary health care provider does not appear
to be doing his job. Additionally, OFS is not following up on Child
A needs in these areas. GAL X reported the OFS worker reported
something about insurance issues affecting getting a second
opinion; but OFS did not address the issues with the Department
of Health and Human Services (DHHS) Purchase of Services
(POS) Worker. GAL X reported the court indicated it does not
care about insurance issues; that Child A needs to get the second
opinion.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) 2 & Foster Care Supervisor 3
On April 6, 2023, I interviewed Foster Care Worker (FCW) 2 and
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) 3, separately, at the OFS office. I
also had an email correspondence with FCS 3 on 4/27/2023.
Both of these OFS employees reported believing OFS had fulfilled
the court order requirement for a second opinion by FCW 2’s
completion of an Early On assessment for Child A.
3

Foster Care Worker 2:
FCW 2 reported being Child A’s case worker since Child A’s
placement with OFS/ Foster Parent B and Foster Parent C on
1/7/2022. FCW 2 reported Child A is a 14-month-old toddler who
is not diagnosed with any specialized needs at this time. As for
Child A’s reported leg and tongue issues, FCW 3 reported Child A
is tongue tied and the foster parents reported that Child A may be
dragging one of her legs. FCW 2 reported Child A’s pediatrician,
Doctor P has not recommended any type of correction for the tied
tongue, at this time. The foster parents reported that Doctor P
informed them at Child A’s last well child exam on 1/6/2023 that it
is unknown how Child A’s tongue-tied issue may affect Child A;
that Child A may eventually outgrow this. FCW 2 reported Doctor
P documented the tongue-tied diagnosis in Child A’s well child
report, but the statements about its possible affects came from the
foster parents. Doctor P had not documented that in any well child
examination report.
FCW 2 reported Child A’s foster parents had reported to the GAL
that Child A drags her right left, but they had not informed her of
this. FCW 2 was unaware of this issue until the GAL reported it at
the 1/23/2023 court hearing. FCW 2 spoke with the foster parents
afterwards about Child A’s leg. The foster parents confirmed that
they thought Child A was dragging Child A’s leg. FCW 2 also
observed Child A. From what FCW 2 observed it appeared Child
A was favoring one leg more than the other, not that Child A was
dragging either leg. Nor that Child A appeared in pain. FCW 2 had
not received medical reports of a significant problem.
FCW 2 reported it was at the 1/23/2023 court hearing that the
matter of a second opinion came up. The court did not just ask for
a second opinion. The GAL asked the court to order the second
opinion. The January 2023 court ‘s order for a second opinion was
only related to Child A’s leg and speech. As for Child A’s speech
FCW 2 reported according to Child A’s foster parents, Child A
would have fits of anger, which they believed came from Child A
not being able to communicate what Child A wants. Child A only
has a few words of vocabulary. In term of Autism, FCW 2 said the
Autism issue did not come up until the March 2023 court hearing,
when the GAL mentioned that Child A could have Autism because
Child A’s five-year-old sister is diagnosed with Autism. FCW 2
reported prior to the GAL mentioning the Autism concern at the
March court hearing, FCW 2 had not noticed Child A displaying
signs of the disorder. Nor had the foster parents mentioned Child
A displaying any signs. The foster parents had only reported that
4

sometimes Child A covers her ears at loud noises. The foster
parents had not specified the type of loud noises. FCW 2 reported
the court did not specify in the March 2023 order to specifically
say anything about a second opinion for Autism; but an
assessment for such would have been a part of the restated order
for OFS to get a second opinion on.
FCW 2 reported she did not obtain, or attempt obtain the
second opinion via a medical doctor related to Child A’s leg and
speech because Child A was being seen medically, OFS did not
have a doctor noting any concerns; and a second opinion was
pursued by her through Early On. Additionally, OFS thought Early
On would be able to complete a developmental assessment, and
refer onward/elsewhere if Child A required other medical services.
I advised FCW 2 getting a second opinion commonly means
getting another medical opinion; and I inquired
why OFS had not done that. FCW 2 reported she spoke with POS
Monitor XX early in February 2023 about what to do about
completing the court’s second opinion order. POS Monitor XX
knew about the order because POS Monitor XX was also at the
January 2023 court hearing. POS Monitor XX reported POS
Monitor XX would confer with the Health Liaison
Officer (HLO) so see what could be done related to insurance
coverage. In middle March 2023 POS Monitor XX reported
Child A’s foster parents would have to pay out of pocket if the
foster parents wanted a second opinion/assessment via a medical
facility, like Beaumont hospital. For Child A’s health
insurance to cover any other medical provider like a Beaumont
hospital provider, the foster parents would need a referral from
Child A’s primary doctor or a referral from Early On. Thus, since
the original court order said second opinion and did not specify.
through a medical doctor, OFS thought it was following the
court’s order with the Early On pursuit..
I asked FCW 2 if the Early On was intended as the second opinion
why was the Early On assessment so late in the timeframe with
respect to the 1/23/2023 court order. FCW 2 denied not acting
timely. She said, she made the Early On referral on 1/31/2023
once the foster parents signed the form. The intake appointment
was set for 2/28/2023; and the assessment was set for
4/5/2023(later changed to 4/7/2023). A family team meeting (FTM)
was held in early February, which was attended by the foster
parents and GAL X. The Early On referral and the time frames for
assessment was discussed at that FTM, no objections were
voiced at that time by anyone. FCW 2 said she reported all of that
same information at the March 2023 court hearing; but that was
5

not sufficient. The GAL wants Child A seen via Beaumont hospital
for the second opinion. FCW 2 reported the plan at this time is to
change Child A’s primary health provider from Doctor P to Doctor
BL. The GAL reported speaking with Doctor BL and Doctor BL
takes Medicaid. POS Monitor XX also reports a number of
children in foster care see Doctor BL, so the health care provider
switch will be done. An examination appointment is set for
4/12/2023.
FCW 2 reported OFS had not explored switching Child A’s primary
medical health care provider to enable them to get the medical
second opinion, because the foster parents had not indicated a
concern with Child A’s health care provider Doctor P. Additionally,
OFS thought the Early On referral would get Child A to an
advance treatment provider; and OFS would select Beaumont.
Furthermore, FCW 2 reported Child A’s foster parents are very
assertive foster parents and if the foster parents felt Child A’s
needs were not being fulfilled these foster parents would not
hesitate to speak up or seek outside sources. FCW 2 was not sure
why the GAL, or court had not suggested switching Child A’s
health care provider earlier.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) 3:
FCS 3 affirmed information as reported by FCW 2 related to why
OFS pursued an Early On referral and assessment as it way of
obtaining a second opinion pertaining to Child A’s reported health
care issues. FCS 3 reported Child A’s foster parents, Foster
Parent B and Foster Parent C did not bring concerns related to
Child A up to FCW 2, but shared them with the GAL. FCS 3
reported Child A has parenting times at OFS and neither FCW 2,
nor Child A’s parents have noticed an issue with Child A’s legs.
FCS 3 reported the GAL does not reach out to FCW 2 or contact
OFS about concerns, in an effort to address them. The GAL only
communicates with the POS monitor. The GAL attended an FTM
before the 1/23/2023 court hearing and the GAL never mentioned
any issues.
On 4/27/2023 FCS 3 provider clarification related OFS possibly
not knowing that Early On was already working with Child A; and
reportedly OFS trying to link Child A up with OFS’s Early On’s
system, as reported by the foster parents. FCS 3 advised that
FCW 2 initially referred Child A for Early On in January or
February of 2022 when Child A entered care. The referral was
assigned to Early On through the Oakland Health Department
(OHD). After Child A was assessed, the foster parents reported
Child A did not qualify for services. OFS was not made aware that
6

Child A was getting monthly nurse check ins through OHD until
OFS made another referral for Early On in January of 2023. The
referral in January of 2023 was made due to the foster parents
reporting to the GAL they had concerns with Child A's speech and
walking. Once OFS made the second Early On referral, OFS was
contacted by the Early On team with OHD stating Child A was
already in services, but the foster parents had not returned any
phone calls from them or participated in the monthly check ins in
several months. FCS 3 reported that somehow the foster parents
made an appointment with Early On at OFS and this was later
canceled by the OFS Early On worker due to that worker seeing
that Child A was already getting Early On services through OHD.
The latter is still in place, and it appears Early On with OHD
attempted to contact the foster parents on 4/12/2023.
POS Monitor XX
On April 14, 2023, I interviewed POS Monitor XX by telephone.
POS Monitor XX reported similar information as FCW 2 related to
the outcome of the 1/23/2023 court hearing; the foster parents
reporting some concern with Child A’s leg and speech to the GAL
which the foster parents had not reported as concerns to the
agency. POS Monitor XX reported at the 1/23/2023 court hearing
the GAL requested a second opinion based on the concerns the
GAL brought up. The GAL reported the second opinion could be
through Beaumont hospital, but it did not have to be through
Beaumont hospital. POS Monitor XX said she enlisted the
assistance of the HLO, pertaining to this matter. She reported,
because they had no documented information related to the health
concerns reported by the GAL the HLO suggested that the agency
go back to Child A’s primary health care doctor. POS Monitor XX
said Child A’s tongue-tied issues was being addressed, Child A
was only 13 months old at that time and the foster parents had not
mentioned a concern with that. The only concern was the speech
and the report of Child A dragging her leg. OFS was working on
going back to Child A’s primary doctor just prior to the March 2023
court hearing. OFS had completed the Early On referral and OFS
thought that would get everything worked out.
POS Monitor XX reported in her experience the Early On
assessment would have been sufficient for evaluation of Child A’s
speech. She was not aware as to whether it would take care of
any needs for occupation therapy. POS Monitor XX did not think
all was as the GAL had indicated. She said, OFS made efforts to
fulfill the court’s orders based on what OFS thought was the
issues. It was because of all that the GAL was requesting that the
agency reached out to POS Monitor XX. The GAL had concerns
7

with Child A’s primary care doctor; the GAL thought Doctor P was
too young, was not as experienced as his mother who was
retiring. The GAL wanted someone more experienced to assess
Child A.
POS Monitor XX reported, the primary health care provider issue
got addressed, and Child A had an appointment with Doctor BL
via Beaumont on 4/14/2023. Doctor BL gave a referral, for Child A
related to the tongue-tied issue through an ENT (Ear, Nose and
Throat) doctor, and for Child A’s leg through a walk and gait
provider. All the referrals were with Beaumont hospital providers.
At the doctor appointment, Doctor BL reported not being
concerned with Child A’s speech because Child A is too young. As
for an Autism assessment, the doctor thought it was too early for
such. POS Monitor XX reported knowing this information because
FCW 2 attended the doctor’s appointment with Child A’s foster
parents and asked questions. Doctor BL reported that Child A
had good eye contact and focus, and that that would not be seen
in a child with Autism. The doctor plans to conduct an
assessment when Child A when Child A is 18 months old.
Foster Parent B and Foster Parent C
On 4/21/2023, via telephone, I spoke with Foster Parent B and
Foster Parent C who was in the background and responded to
Foster Parent B when she asked him to verify certain things.
These foster parents reported when Child A was placed with them
in January of 2022, Child A had no identified special needs.
They reported the first health concern they reach out to OFS
about with respect to Child A was Child A having breathing issues.
Child A was turning blue. The breathing issues occurred earlier
within the placement, and they cleared up. Those breathing issues
may have been related to smoke; Child A was coming home from
her birth parent visits smelling of smoke. At three months of age
Child A was diagnosed as being tongue tied and this issue was
also reported to FCW 2. Neither Foster Parent B nor Foster
Parent C reported there being anything FCW 2 or OFS were to do
or followed up on related to Child A’s tongue issue. That the
doctor had indicated Child A’s tongue would need to be clipped at
some point but expressed no need to do so at any particular point
in time. That as Child A’s foster parents, they would just continue
to follow up with the doctor.
Foster Parent B reported other issues she reported to FCW 2
were Child A having swallowing issues, being very aggressive
(hitting, biting, kicking) and Child A appearing to experience some
difficulty lifting her right side/leg. As for the leg issue, Foster
8

Parent B noticed that some time in December 2022, once Child A
began walking, Child A was dragging her leg and walking
sideway. Foster Parent B acknowledged that they took Child A to
see Child A’s doctor for these issues. Foster Parent B did not
report what the doctor reported, about Child A’s swallowing or
aggressive behavior; she reported the doctor (whom she referred
to as a she) indicated the leg issue may be related to hypotonia.
The doctor reported there was no need to do anything now.
Foster Parent B said she also spoke with the GAL about the
issues, after the GAL called her about a Team’s meeting the GAL
had learned about. During the conversation, she told the GAL
about Child A’s leg difficulty, that they had Child A’s walking
assessed; and it possibly being hypotonia. The GAL did not know
about this issue. She also told the GAL the agency said that per
Doctor P, it’s nothing major. The GAL seemed more concerned
than the agency. The GAL asked whether they had discussed
getting a second opinion; then the GAL advocated for a second
opinion at court. After the court hearing, the FCW 2 reached out
to them and reported that OFS would get a second opinion, but
that there was an issue with Child A’s health insurance covering it.
FCW 2 never reported anything about an Early On assessment
being the second opinion. Foster Parent B reported OFS
completed an Early On referral and wanted Child A to see the
Early On provider through their organization. An intake
appointment was set for 2/28/2023, but no one came out. Once it
was discovered or realized that Child A was already with Early On,
the 2/28/2023 appointment was changed. OFS had apparently
forgotten that Child A was already in Early On through another
system that they had referred Child A with earlier in 2022. The
latter referral/service was still during COVID, so the Early On
nurse/representative was not coming to the foster home.
Nurse/Representative LG called once a month and did Zoom
contacts.
Foster Parent B reported after the second opinion was arranged
via Beaumont hospital provider, Doctor BL, Child A was seen by
that doctor on 4/12/2023; and they also saw Nurse/Representative
LG for an Early On assessment that same day. Foster Parent B
denied telling the GAL information different than what she had
reported to OFS. She said the GAL just seemed to take her
reports of concern more serious.
Document Review:
Child A’s MISACWIS Case record which showed:
9

• Child A is currently 16 months of age. She was placed
under OFS’s supervision, and in-Foster Parent B’s and
Foster C’s foster home on 1/7/2022.
• She is a temporary court ward who at initial placement
was diagnosed as a heathy baby requiring normal care.
• Child A was reported to be tongue tied; no corrective
action was documented as needed at this time.
• A 3/28/2022 well child examination had indicated Child A
might have hypertonia, where it is hard for her to move her
neck, arm, muscles. That this is being monitored to
determine if Child A requires services.
• Child A’s pediatrician’s office referred her for a
neurological appointment that was set for 7/28/2022.The
doctor determined the appointment was no longer
necessary following Child A’s six month’s well child
examination that showed she was improving.
• A 10/22/2022 well examination had indicated Child A was
continuing to improve, making progress and no extra
services were needed related to hypotonia. Child A was
reported to be on track developmentally.
• That a January 2023 well child examination indicated the
same as the October 2022 well child examination related
to Child A’s wellness and development..
• An Early On assessment was pending for 4/5/2023 to
assess Child A’s speech and walking concerns.
Copies of Child A’s well child exams referenced above (3/28/2022,
10/10/2022) from Child A’s pediatrician’s office. Also copies of well
child examinations for 1/17/2022, 2/14/2022, and 1/6/2023.
• The 1/17/2022 well child document indicated the patient
has an appointment for echocardiogram, however physical
examine reveals no cardiac pathology.
• The 2/14/2022 well child document also referenced well
child, and hypotonia.
• The 1/6/2023 well child document indicated, well child.
A January 23, 2023, Oakland County Court Order that indicated:
• “DHHS to refer the child for a second opinion for the child’s
physical and speech issues.”
Early On referrals completed by OFS dated for:
• 1/24/2022 (reason indicated, to “establish medical
condition”) The referral had other assessment documents
(ages, stage questionnaire/worksheet, nurse’s statement).
• And 1/31/2023.
10

Documentation via emails showing:
• FCW 2’s effort to obtain POS Monitor XX’s assistance
related to getting Child A assessed via a Beaumont hospital
provider.
• FCW 2 seeking clarification and following up with the GAL
and POS Monitor XX related to the suggestion by the GAL
to have Child A’s primary health care provider switched to
Doctor BL so as to obtain a medical second opinion.
Analysis Based on interviews and documentations, there is insufficient
evidence to show that OFS did not seek to have the child’s
physical and medical needs serviced. Nor that they did not seek to
obtain a second opinion related to concerns reported related to
Child A’s leg/walk and speech:
• Child A’s medical and physical care was being provided for
and monitored by her primary pediatrician via the
University Drive Medical Center. Concerns with her
leg/walk was reported by that pediatrician as possible
hypotonia and monitored. This doctor reported the
hypotonia “improved, graduated from neuro”. That Child A
graduated from requiring further services/a neurological
service.
• FCW 2/OFS sought to obtain an Early On developmental
assessment for Child A, as a way to obtain a second
opinion of her developmental concerns; and if further
services were assessed as required, the services could be
paid for via Child A’s health insurance. Such services
would be inclusive of being serviced via a Beaumont
hospital provider, as Child A’s GAL had mentioned to the
court in January 2023.
• Once it became clear that a second opinion was meant to
be by way of another pediatric provider the agency worked
with the GAL and POS Monitor XX to have Child A’s
primary health care provider switched; and Child A
obtained a second medical opinion via her new primary
health care provider Doctor PL.
VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
11
